content: Figure 1: Changing the location of relevant information (in this case, the position of the passage that answers an input question) within the language model’s input context results in a U-shaped performance curve—models are better at using relevant information that occurs at the very beginning (primacy bias) or end of the input context (recency bias), and performance degrades significantly when models must access and use information located in the middle of its input context.
heading_hierarchy: Lost in the Middle: How Language Models Use Long Contexts
